item.title: Sinosphere: North Korean Pop Group Visits Beijing on Soft-Power Mission
item.description: The all-female Moranbong Band, Kim Jong-un’s favorite group, is visiting Beijing at a time when China and North Korea are trying to strengthen ties.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Hyon Song-wol, who leads North Korea’s all-female Moranbong Band, arriving at a hotel in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: An Enduring and Erudite Court Jester in Britain
item.description: Ian Hislop has edited the British satirical magazine Private Eye, a mix of jokes and investigative journalism, for three decades.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ian Hislop is the editor of the satirical British magazine Private Eye.

item.title: Sinosphere: A Wordless Elegy for China’s War Dead
item.description: A requiem for the millions of Chinese killed during World War II and in the years leading up to it will take to the stage in Beijing just once.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The composer Wang Xilin at his home in Beijing. His symphony will have its premiere on Dec. 13.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Return of History
item.description: From the Islamic State to Sri Lanka, modern people are looking to connect with an ancient past.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Geneva Raises Level of Alert for Possible Terrorism Suspects
item.description: The precaution came on the eve of diplomatic talks on Syria between senior American and Russian officials and a United Nations special envoy.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Swiss police officers outside the European headquarters of the United Nations in Geneva on Thursday.

item.title: North and South Korea Meet in Latest Bid to Improve Relations
item.description: Few analysts expected any major breakthroughs from the talks, which were being led by a vice minister from each side.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Hwang Boo-gi, left, South Korea’s vice minister for unification, shaking hands with his North Korean counterpart, Jon Jong-su, during a meeting at the Kaesong industrial complex just inside North Korea.

item.title: Key to Success of Climate Pact Will Be Its Signals to Global Markets
item.description: Diplomats and policy experts say that a pact must convince companies and investors that traditional fossil fuels are less profitable.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Ladislas Ntaganzwa, Top Suspect in Rwandan Genocide, Is Arrested
item.description: The United Nations said Mr. Ntaganzwa, one of nine remaining fugitives sought for his role in the 1994 genocide, was arrested this week in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Tossed Glass of Wine Hits Nerve in Brazil
item.description: A squabble in which one of Brazil’s most powerful men insulted one of its most powerful women, and wound up with a face full of wine, touched a nerve in a country with a tradition of sexist comments.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Syrian Rebels Form Bloc for New Round of Peace Talks
item.description: Syrian opposition groups put aside their grievances to form one body as a prerequisite for new talks with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and rebels and government forces agreed to a truce in Homs.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Syrian civilians, who left the city of Homs under a truce between rebels and the government, were bused to Idlib on Thursday.

item.title: Finnish Police Arrest Iraqi Twins Linked to ISIS Massacre in 2014
item.description: The arrests announced on Thursday threatened to fan an already simmering anti-immigrant backlash in Finland and Europe as a whole.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Republicans Make Presence Felt at Climate Talks by Ignoring Them
item.description: The party’s unyielding approach in treating the climate talks as a waste of time has even sympathizers shaking their heads.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sinosphere: Amid China’s Smog Worries, One More: Counterfeit Masks
item.description: A report said the Shanghai authorities had seized 120,000 counterfeit surgical masks, the kind commonly worn to protect against polluted air.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: People in Beijing wearing face masks on Wednesday. Such masks have become an increasingly common sight in China in recent years.

item.title: Death Toll From Hajj Stampede Reaches 2,411 in New Estimate
item.description: The tally of 2,411, compiled by The Associated Press, is triple the official Saudi toll and would be the worst stampede in the history of the hajj.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Saudi Press Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pilgrims on their way to perform a ritual known as the Stoning of the Devil on the first day of the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha in September in Mina, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Vatican Says Catholics Should Not Try to Convert Jews
item.description: A new document meant to solidify the Vatican’s increasingly positive relations with Jews says members should work to fight anti-Semitism.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Voter Insecurities Feed Rise of Right-Leaning Populist Politicians
item.description: Financial worries and fears about terrorism and immigration are contributing to a rise in right-wing politicians in Europe similar to Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Israel Hails ‘Successful’ Test of Antiballistic Missile System
item.description: Israel said the Arrow 3 system, which is being jointly developed with the United States, intercepted a target just outside the earth’s atmosphere.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The test launch of the Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system near Ashdod, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Open Source: Irish Women Who Had Abortions Abroad Show Their Faces Online
item.description: A new social media campaign aims to build support to change the law that makes it nearly impossible to legally terminate a pregnancy in Ireland.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Donald Trump Pushes Back at British Petition to Bar Him
item.description: The presidential candidate’s comments that Muslims should be barred from the United States prompted an online petition calling for him to be refused entry into Britain.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump has also gained some support in Britain, and a counterpetition titled “Don’t Ban Trump From the United Kingdom” has more than 10,000 signatures.

item.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Agree to Reopen Talks With an Absent Taliban
item.description: While the Afghan president was in Pakistan for meetings on restarting peace talks, the Taliban besieged buildings in Kandahar, casting doubt on their interest in diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Lorenzo Tugnoli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rahmatullah Nabil at his office in Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2014. Mr. Nabil resigned as his country’s intelligence chief on Thursday.
